title: Domain 1.1: Given a scenario, install and configure laptop hardware components
content:
üß∞ INSTALLING & CONFIGURING LAPTOP HARDWARE + SECURITY COMPONENTS

üîã 1. Battery Replacement

Removable batteries (older laptops): Slide a latch, pop it out.
Integrated batteries (newer ultrabooks): Require removing screws and the back panel.

‚ö†Ô∏è ESD Safety Tip: Always turn off the device, unplug the power source, and ground yourself before opening.

üß† EXAM TIP: Know how to identify removable vs. non-removable batteries. Be ready to answer which tools you‚Äôd use (like a plastic spudger or screwdriver).

üéπ 2. Keyboard Replacement

Most laptop keyboards are attached with screws and a thin ribbon cable. Replacing one often requires removing the top panel or palm rest.
Common issues: dead keys, water damage, or physical damage.

üß† EXAM TIP: You might see a diagram and be asked where the ribbon cable connects. Know that ribbon cables go to ZIF (Zero Insertion Force) connectors.

üß† 3. RAM Replacement/Upgrade

SODIMM (Small Outline Dual In-line Memory Module) is used in laptops.
Usually accessible through a bottom panel or under the keyboard. Push clips outward ‚Üí RAM pops up ‚Üí insert new one at a 45¬∞ angle.

üß† EXAM TIP: Know that adding more RAM improves multitasking and performance. Also recognize SODIMM vs. DIMM.

üíæ 4. HDD/SSD Replacement or Migration

Laptops use 2.5" SATA HDDs/SSDs, NVMe M.2 SSDs, or both.
Migration = moving OS and data to a new drive using cloning software (e.g., Macrium Reflect, Clonezilla).
Replacement = physically removing the old drive and installing a new one.

üß† EXAM TIP: Know which tools are needed (e.g., Phillips screwdriver), what form factors to expect (2.5", M.2), and what cloning means.

üì∂ 5. Wireless Card Replacement

Usually a mini PCIe or M.2 card, often under a back panel. Connected to antenna wires (black/white) that clip on. Secure with screws.

üß† EXAM TIP: You may see questions on which wires are used for Wi-Fi antennas. Know where this card is located and how to identify it.

üîê 6. Biometrics

Devices that use fingerprint scanners, face recognition, etc., usually built into the palm rest or near the touchpad.

üß† EXAM TIP: Biometrics is part of physical security. Know what it protects (device access, data) and how it‚Äôs configured (usually in the OS or BIOS/UEFI).

üì° 7. Near-Field Scanner Features (NFC)

NFC (Near Field Communication) allows short-range communication (about 4 cm). Used for tap-to-pay, smartcard logins, and device pairing.
Some laptops have NFC sensors embedded in the palm rest or under the keyboard.

üß† EXAM TIP: Know that NFC is short-range. Differentiate it from Bluetooth or Wi-Fi.
